major_name: Bachelor of Applied Science Degree Requirements
topics: An examination of the major factors giving rise to distinctive styles of urban spatial organization.
The best planning practices from developing countries are being used in some western industrialized countries, and vice versa.

Based on current globalization and learning from best planning practices worldwide, this course will offer comparative analysis of urban spatial structure and urban form, as well as administrative and regulatory implications of urbanization around world.
Be aware of the evolution of the urban systems in each world region

course_name: PLAN415 - Urban Planning and Development in Transitional China (0.50)
major_name: Bachelor of Applied Science Degree Requirements
topics: Urban Planning and Development in Transitional China Winter 2024
This course offers a critical understanding of China's urban planning and development in the context of the country's economic reform and globalization.

To understand China’s fundamental and gradualist approach toward economic reform and the dichotomy of the political-economic legacy from the planned economy era and the so-called socialist market-oriented economy
To gain a critical understanding of the central underpinnings of China’s post-reform urban planning and development in a global context
To become familiar with current debates and recent empirical cases in the field of urban China studies

To develop the ability to identify, narrate and frame research questions in the Chinese context, and develop a critical perspective for understanding the most current issues in China and its impact global-wise
General Introduction; China’s geographical setting and traditional cities
Pre-socialist urbanization; Uneven regional development
The design dimension of China's planning system: urban design for development control.
Migration and population mobility; Migration and labor market
Migration and development in China: Trends, geography and current issues.
Urban economy; space and architecture in globalization
Urban infrastructure; Transnational network and new economic space

Land markets and management; Urban housing

Environmental quality and sustainability; Urban expansion and suburbanization

topics: Introduction to Leisure, Equity, Diversity, and Inclusion for Just Communities Fall 2024

Topics for critique and resistance may include, but are not limited to gentrification, capitalism, settler colonialisms, environmental injustice, and other systemic barriers at play within our leisure lives and communities.

The purpose of this course is to enhance students' understanding of leisure in contemporary society by examining the beliefs, values, and social structures of their own leisure and comparing and contrasting them with the individual and social considerations of diversity, multiculturalism and social justice.
Describe how the spaces and places of leisure reflect and reproduce cultural values, social role expectations, stereotypes, and hegemony
Compare and contrast non-normative leisure across cultures and sub-cultures to explain how leisure reflects and reproduces cultural values, social role expectations, stereotypes, and hegemony
Discuss how dominant cultural values influence leisure, including decisions about which populations are served in public, private, and commercial recreation
Explain the relationship between leisure, equality/equity in relation to race/ethnicity, sex/gender, economic status, ability, sexuality, religion, and other cultural influences
Create and support suggestions for individual and societal action related to leisure, the individual, and the "common good," specifically as it addresses marginalized/oppressed communities

major_name: Bachelor of Applied Science Degree Requirements
topics: History of Western Sport Spring 2024
amanda.hooper@uwaterloo.ca
This course considers the historical impact of sport in the western part of the world, especially Europe and North America.

The connections between sport and social and cultural divisions in western history will be examined not only through consideration of how gender, class, ethnicity, religion, and region have sometimes divided views and attitudes toward sport, but also how the experience of sports by players or spectators have brought different groups to associate together.

Sports can send messages regarding fundamental beliefs and values (one example being that Black and white baseball players in the age of segregation rarely played against one another), and the historical revelations that these messages contain will serve as our focal point throughout much of this course.
Identify various roles sport has played in the historical development of a number of nations in the West;
Distinguish different ways in which sport has influenced society and culture in the West;
Engage in historical analysis to examine how sport has illustrated the changes experienced by various societies in the West.

It focuses both on the theoretical aspects of aging and their implications for leisure and on the practical aspects of recreation and leisure program development, delivery, and facilitation for all older adults.

critically reflect on understandings of old age, ageing, and stereotypes of ageing, how these understandings shape interactions with older adults in recreation contexts, and how leisure and recreation shape these understandings and perpetuate ageism in our society

critique notions of successful ageing and explored the connections between leisure, ageing well, and age-inclusive communities
explore and compare the variety of leisure opportunities, programs and services available for, and utilized by, diverse older adults in the community and in long-term care settings

course_name: VCULT101 - Art History and Visual Culture (0.50)
major_name: Bachelor of Applied Science Degree Requirements
topics: This course takes a case study approach to examining the role of the art object as a means of communication within the history of visual culture.
We might think of the themes as case studies.
We will also focus with equal intensity on the properties of visuality, i.e. how do images and objects communicate effectively?

The primary goals of the course are to recognize the significant role visual culture plays in human history and human societies AND to develop the analytical skills and vocabulary to discuss images and objects within that context.

Be introduced to, and develop basic research skills, for the study of visual images and objects by: using a range of resources and recognizing the parameters and properties of each (websites, newspapers, academic texts, interviews, films, etc.), and learning to access resources through the UW Library and other providers and platforms

Become aware of, and actively engage with modes of decolonization by: becoming aware of power dynamics of forms of visual culture, recognizing the function/role of various forms of visual culture within various cultures, recognizing and understanding that there are multiple ways of knowing, and recognizing and understanding that multiple ways of knowing are communicated in various modes of visual culture and by various forms of analysis

SI 312: View requirements for SI 312
Analysis of a special topic in anthropology, as announced by the department.
These include religious and cultural rituals, social worlds, and political lives of Muslims in a variety of geographical areas from Asia to North America.

This means that we are not interested as much in the different juridical interpretations of Islam as a religion, but in the diversity of the ways in which Muslims construct their religious, political, and cultural identities in practice.
Selected case studies raise issues concerning Islam in modern times such as ritual, language, gender, authority, representation, stereotypes, race, and secularism.

topics: Notice of Recording
Principles of Economics Winter 2025
Instructor: Alain-Désiré Nimubona
E-mail Address: animubona@uwaterloo.ca
This course provides an introduction to the basic concepts and tools of micro and macro economic analysis of individuals, businesses, and government in the global world.
View requirements for ECON 100
Microeconomics is the study of economic behaviour of individual consumers and firms, and the distribution of total production and income among them.
It involves the determination of prices through the optimizing behaviour of economic agents, with consumers maximizing their wellbeing and firms maximizing their profits.

Macroeconomics takes a wider view of the economy; it studies the overall performance of an economy including growth in incomes, changes in the overall level of prices and the employment and unemployment rates.
This course offers an introduction to the basic theories in microeconomics and macroeconomics.
Understand consumers and producers' decision-making processes
Analyse consumers’ wellbeing and firms’ performance in different market structures
Understand the rationale as well as the consequences of government intervention in the market system
Learn the relationships among major macroeconomic variables in simple models
Comprehend the main tradeoffs involved in macroeconomic policy making
Apply economic models to explain real world problems.
Week 1: Introduction to the Course / The Economic Problem
Week 2: Demand and Supply
Monopoly and Imperfect Competition
Week 9: Economic Welfare, the Environment and Income Distribution

topics: Statistics for Economists Winter 2025
ECON 221
ECON 221 001
Email: pchausse@uwaterloo.ca
Clinic: There is a clinic to help students with ECON 211 and ECON 221 every Tuesday and Wednesday from 3:00PM to 4:30PM in HH 235.
ECON 221:
This course introduces students to describing economic data and drawing inferences from features of economic data.

Starting from fundamental axioms of probability, students will learn about the calculation of probabilities of basic events and the features of random variables, the most important tool for representing the outcomes of complex economic phenomena.

Students will describe discrete and continuous random variables via their probability distributions and summary statistics such as means and standard deviations, as well as the relationships between two random variables in terms of covariance, correlation, and simple regression models.

The concepts of hypothesis testing and confidence intervals, and the fundamentals of statistical inference are discussed for basic features of random variables and for comparing the features of more than one random variable.

This course introduces the method of Cost-Benefit Analysis, which is instrumental in providing policy makers with specialized tools and information for determining the economic merits of various projects.

Relying on basic principles of microeconomics, the course will develop a sound understanding of the main advantages and limitations of the Cost Benefit Analysis method, along with a proficiency in both assessing and conducting such analyses in practice.

New topics include updated discussions – based on the latest research – on experimental and behavioural evidence associated with non-pecuniary effects of employment, the social discount rate in the context of climate change mitigation and adaptation, cost-effectiveness and cost-utility analysis.

This course provides an in-depth exploration of strategic decision-making with uncertainty and its applications in economics, computer science, and beyond.
The journey begins with games of incomplete information, introducing solution concepts such as Bayes-Nash equilibrium.
The course then transitions to mechanism design and market design, emphasizing their mathematical underpinnings and practical applications.

For multi-agent environments, we explore dominant strategy and Bayesian implementation, applying these concepts to real-world settings like auction design, matching markets, and school choice problems.
This advanced treatment blends theoretical rigor with practical insights, equipping students with tools to analyze and design strategic interactions in complex settings.
Design mechanisms that align individual incentives with desired outcomes in single- and multi-agent settings
Apply theoretical tools to real-world problems like auction design and matching market design

Week 13: Additional topics such as matching markets and school choice problems

This course examines different possibilities for community organizing, exploring the limits and possibilities for each within the Canadian legislative and regulatory environment.
It seeks to give students both theoretical and practical knowledge that can be applied to a variety of organizing settings and issues.
It uses case studies, theoretical analysis/reflection and movement literatures to discuss a range of organizing activities, problems and practicalities across an array of movements and issues.
Each reading brings forth a new set of considerations and/or tools to aid in the expansion understandings of social movement politics and the possibilities for social change in the real world.
This includes the ethics and values that can be used to analyze and action with regard to a number of issues that are active and ongoing in our world.

Public policy responses to crime includes patterns in police decision making about what constitutes a crime, expert and lay theories on the causes of crime, political pronouncements on what to do about criminal offenders, and beliefs about the purposes of incarceration, amongst other formal and informal facets of the criminal justice system.

Focusing on the experience of marginalized groups such as youth, women, and racialized persons, this course will help students develop a critical understanding of the ways in which public policy responses to crime can reproduce wider patterns of discrimination in society, especially those pertaining to race and Indigeneity.
Formal social control operates at the macro level in the form of laws and criminal justice policy.

To this end, aspects of the nexus between law and society are examined to explore the efficacy of the criminal justice system to respond to complex social problems, marginalized populations, and dangerous offenders.

course_name: LS425 - Crossing Borders: Law and Global Deviance (0.50)
major_name: Bachelor of Applied Science Degree Requirements
topics: Email: vferreri@uwaterloo.ca
This seminar covers anthropological perspectives on the relationship between state borders and socio-cultural boundaries (across race, gender, class, language, and religion).
Anthropology has always been a discipline crossing different types of borders and boundaries in its quest to study and understand other cultures, modes of being, and forms of knowledge.

Through this lens, the course examines the role of social and cultural boundaries and state borders in relation to the law and legal (and political) regimes to reflect on the mechanism of inclusion and exclusion, and the production of taxonomies characterising border-crossers and borderland communities.
The course begins with retracing the rise of an anthropology of borders and its relationship to classical conceptualizations of boundaries in early anthropological work.

We will examine how war, displacement, settler colonialism and late capitalism shape borderlands, border-dwellers and crossers to unpack key concepts in the studies of borders such as affect, sovereignty, humanitarianism, hospitality, waiting and migration regimes.

By reading ethnographies of border-crossers, we will interrogate the relationship between (il-)legality and the social world of border-crossers and dwellers in which life and death become engrained in mundane objects, documents, bureaucracy, different forms of violence and solidarity.

Through these different themes, the course is also an exploration of the ethics and politics of doing ethnographic research, writing and representing such zones of contact and separation and the people inhabiting them.
Identify and understand key anthropological debates about borders and boundaries and their relationship to law and legal regimes
Demonstrate an understanding of how anthropology can contribute methodologically and theoretically to the interdisciplinary field of border and migration studies
Develop ethnograpically-oriented reading, research, and thinking skills on the topic of borders and boundaries
Critically engage with global news media on matters of migration, refugees, and border politics
Better understand the ethical connections between our own lives and those of others separated through communal, temporal, symbolic, territorial, and racial boundaries.
Each week, we will examine an aspect or a multiplicity of aspects tied to borders and boundaries.

Territorial Acknowledgement: As we will discuss in this course, the Western criminal legal system and its institutions and mechanisms of incarceration, control and confinement are rooted in settler colonialism and chattel slavery as well as white supremacist values and ethics.
It is critical for us to grapple with the persistence of settler colonialism and the afterlives of slavery.
we must understand the imperative nature of
We must face the fact that much of our current system
for responding to deadly local and international conflict
is incapable of overcoming cycles of violent patterns
precisely because our imagination has been corralled and shackled
by the very parameters and sources that create and perpetuate violence."
- John Paul Lederach, Anabaptist peace scholar in
How have religion and religious values contributed to policing and incarceration in Canada and the U.S., and their especially deadly impacts on Black and Indigenous lives?

How can anti-racist, decolonial and feminist approaches to moral imagination enable the potential abolition of policing and prisons, and the creation of a new society in which safety is not premised on violence?
Students actively engaged in reading and class will benefit most from this course.
Explain the role of religious, settler colonial and white supremacist imaginations in the creation and expansion of policing and prisons in Canada and the U.S.
Describe how and why* activists, scholars, and social movements envision the abolition of carceral systems and institutions as critical to peace and justice.
Assess moral values, principles and practices shared by abolitionist movements in relation to their potential to generate safety, healing and accountability.
We will give greater attention to the substance of abolitionist dreaming and the moral compass that guides these visions.
Religion, Justice, and the Abolition of Prisons /Joshua Dubler and Vincent Lloyd.
Imagined Futures Project 25%
C: Critique of ideas in the text(s): What do you want to affirm as well as challenge?
In addition to offering focused contributions, demonstrate reflective listening and be mindful of nonverbal communication.

Per the analysis of Joshua Dubler and Vincent Lloyd among other activist-scholars, incarceration is not only positioned as a political and economic solution to societal challenges but also a moral and ethical solution.

Depict a future in which carceral systems and institutions no longer exist and there are solutions and strategies guided by emancipatory morals and values that address societal challenges of direct and structural violence.
Your project should clearly depict the solution(s) including specific strategies and practices and the values that they reflect.

The non-carceral future you depict must also be directly informed by solutions, strategies, practices and values within contemporary abolitionist movements, particularly those rooted in Black radical feminisms.

Math For Good and Evil is built on the conviction that the kinds of problems mathematicians and computer scientists seek to address, and the ways they address them, should matter for anyone interested in advancing peace in the world.
The peace implications of math and computer science are explored in connection to topics such as wealth, democracy, policing, oppression, environment, and health.
Math and computer science are tools of enormous and increasing power that impact our daily lives in thousands of ways that we seldom recognize.
Many of the ways that these disciplines have affected us are very beneficial and have transformed the lives of millions of people for the better.
Without peace studies understanding how math can be appropriately harnessed for good, peace theory will be inadequate to prepare students for the twenty-first century.

major_name: Bachelor of Applied Science Degree Requirements
topics: Introduction to Formal Logic Winter 2025
This everyday use of the word takes being illogical to be the same thing as engaging in bad thinking.

Innovations and discoveries in formal logic lie at the heart of important developments in many disciplines, including cognitive science and artificial intelligence, theoretical computer science, linguistics, the foundations of mathematics, and others.

Moreover, it is virtually impossible to read and understand large parts of the philosophical literature of the past 100 years without a good grasp of at least the basics of formal logic; this is most obvious in philosophy of science, philosophy of language, and epistemology, but is also true in areas like metaphysics, including meta-ethics and aesthetics.
You can regard it as a tool that helps you do a better job evaluating the reasoning of others and for improving your own.
What idealizations are we making in supposing them to apply?

If we produce a justification for belief in the correctness of the system, how do we know that the reasoning we use in our justification is correct if the inferences in the justification are part of the system?
We shall also devote some attention to such theoretical and philosophical issues along the way.
We will begin with a short introduction to the basic concepts of logic, such as consistency, validity, and logical truth.

If an ideal logical system would capture all (and only) the correct patterns of inference, each of these systems can be regarded as an approximation to this ideal which captures some but not all valid patterns of inference.

For each system we will study: the relationship between the language of the system and ordinary languages like English; the relationship between validity in the system and logical validity; and various methods for showing validity (such as proof procedures) and invalidity (including semantic methods for producing counter-examples) of patterns of inference.
We will conclude with a brief introduction to some of the metalogical concepts, such as soundness and completeness, that are the core of many more advanced studies in logic.
translate sentences of English into symbolic logic;
explain the core concepts of logic;
articulate the relationships between core logical concepts and their formal counterparts in both sentential logic and predicate logic;
identify key simplifying assumptions of sentential logic and predicate logic;
explain the philosophical significance of the key simplifying assumptions of sentential and predicate logic;
describe various desirable metalogical properties a system of logic might have, and their relationship to the strength of the system; and

Quantum theory is the branch of physics that describes entities and processes at sub-microscopic distance scales.
Quantum mechanics has notoriously resisted our best efforts at interpretation.
This course is suitable for students with a background in either philosophy, physics, or mathematics; knowledge of quantum theory will not be presupposed.

major_name: Bachelor of Applied Science Degree Requirements
topics: Basic Research Methods Winter 2025
People are naturally curious about one another's behaviour patterns and their underlying causes.
Psychological questions are a popular topic both in everyday conversations and in popular media.
How can we evaluate whether a new type of therapy is effective for treating psychological disorders?
Why do people make decisions that they later regret even though the harmful consequences were foreseeable?
What determines whether a romantic couple will stay together or break up?

Research methods encompass the principles and strategies that guide how psychologists collect and interpret information to answer these sorts of questions in order to build an accurate understanding of the mind and behaviour.
We will review the rationale for using particular methods and the principles for evaluating the quality of these methods.
prepare you to conduct well-designed psychological investigations of your own,
become a more informed and critical consumer of research, and
This course begins with important ethical considerations that first must be considered when conducting research.
It touches on methods for generating hypotheses, developing one's skill in generating insightful hypotheses, and assessing the validity of hypotheses.
Specifically, this course will provide students with the opportunity to explore important topics and skills in psychological research including how to
design scales that elicit meaningful responses,
assess the relative strengths and limitations of different methodologies including self-report surveys, lab experiments, and field studies.
Think and Respond Self-Assessment and Workbook Questions
These self-assessment questions are a core aspect of this course.

Skipping these questions and not checking the feedback will result in missing some core content and knowledge that will be tested in various different graded assessments in this course (i.e., assignments, quizzes, and final examination).
Discussions
Discussions will be graded, with the expectation that each student make a meaningful contribution to the discussion and respond to other group member's posts.
Assignments are designed to assess your understanding of key concepts from the course modules through structured exercises.
These assignments will challenge you to apply your understanding of key concepts to complete practical tasks and to evaluate the quality of specific research designs.
The completion of these assignments will allow you to put your knowledge into practice and demonstrate your learning of research principles in a variety of ways.
critically evaluate research as it is presented in popular media and academic articles,
discuss and evaluate techniques that researchers use to test the reliability and validity of measures,

major_name: Bachelor of Applied Science Degree Requirements
topics: Basic Data Analysis Spring 2024
E. Meyers
Your instructor checks email and the Ask the Instructor discussion topic frequently and will make every effort to reply to your questions within 24–48 hours, Monday to Friday.
Instructor: Ethan Meyers
An introduction to the logic and methods of descriptive and inferential statistics with emphasis on application in Psychology.

Topics covered include measures of central tendency and variability, distributions, the normal distribution, z-scores, hypothesis testing, probability, chi-square tests, t-tests, power, and correlation and regression.
In this course, you will learn the basics of using descriptive and inferential statistics in the analysis of psychological data.
This course emphasizes an understanding of fundamental statistical principles rather than "cookbook" application of statistical formulas.
The principles provided in this course will serve as a foundation for more advanced statistical techniques that you may study in later courses.
An appreciation of basic statistical principles, furthermore, can help you to be a more critical "consumer" of reported research findings.
Examine and describe distributions
Estimate measures of of central tendency and spread
Test statistical hypotheses for independent samples and matched pairs
Understand and apply the basic principles of chi-square, t-tests, ANOVA and Regression
Develop a basic intuition for, and be able to describe, power analysis and effect size
Strategies for Success
Do the practice exercises in the online textbook and the practice questions that appear under each week’s lessons.
Statistical computation needs to be internalized through continuous training and it will not work as effectively if you try to cram everything in the night before assessments.
Week 1: Introduction to Statistics, Measures of Spread, and Relationships
Week 5: Introduction to Inference and Estimation
Week 6: Hypothesis Testing - One Sample Tests
Week 8:  Inference for Relationships Between Multiple Variables: t-tests
Week 9: Inference for Relationships Between Multiple Variables: ANOVA and Chi-Square
Week 11 & 12: Inference for Relationships Between Multiple Variables: Regression
